item.title: Dear Dad: I went to a Cubs game
item.dc:creator: Jenna
item.description: My dad . . . my poor dad. He tried to get me into sports, he really did. When we lived in Spain he would turn on the occasional soccer game and even try to explain some of what was happening. At that point, I would scurry away to go play dolls in my room. Or read [...]

item.title: Chiang Dao: Fairytale Thailand
item.dc:creator: eidolonfilms
item.description: I’ve been dreaming of glistening rice paddies, families packed four to a motorbike, hillside villages overrun with cute children and mist covered mountain tops.  They’re the fairy tale images I had of Thailand.  And I discovered them all in Chiang Dao, a small town just an hour and half bus ride north of Chiang Mai. [...]
item.content:encoded:
Woman selling longan, a lychee-like fruit grown in Thailand.

I’ve been dreaming of glistening rice paddies, families packed four to a motorbike, hillside villages overrun with cute children and mist covered mountain tops.  They’re the fairy tale images I had of Thailand.  And I discovered them all in Chiang Dao, a small town just an hour and half bus ride north of Chiang Mai. So beautiful this place was, we lingered an extra day.

Durian, Rambutan and Mangosteen.

We arrived in Chiang Dao around 11am, just in time to catch the tail end of the Tuesday morning market when hill tribes come to town to sell fruit and vegetables. We bought sliced durian fruit, mangosteens, rambutans, cherry tomatoes, cucumbers and a hulking avocado (later to be eaten like an apple!) before catching a taxi for the fifteen minute ride to our mountainside stay, Chiang Dao Nest.

Misty mountain view from Chiang Dao Nest.

As we rode, the trees got taller and the mist thicker.  Tucked behind a curve in the road was a collection of thatched roof bungalows connected by gravel footpaths.  We were greeted with fresh lemongrass juice and invited to drop our bags at a cozy little bungalow with a private porch and a large king sized bed dressed in hand-made tribal fabrics. It was raining heavily, so we found shelter beneath a large thatch roof covered platform with tons of colorful floor cushions. There we spent the afternoon reading and listening to the percussive song of a diversity of birds.

Lemongrass juice on arrival at Nest.

Rain that lasted for three days.

When the rain slowed, we grabbed umbrellas and ventured to Chiang Dao cave, a 10 minute walk away.  The cave was filled with Buddhas and a pond with supposedly sacred fish, though that pond had become heavily flooded due to the non-stop rain.  There were few people around and in the rain and mist, the area had a certain magical quality to it.

The road to Chiang Dao cave.

Dogs hanging out near Chiang Dao cave.

Old Chedi outside the Chiang Dao cave.

We wandered back for dinner at the restaurant at Nest.  Chef Wicha has two restaurants within walking distance of one another. One serving inventive “western” food and the other offering creative Northern Thai cuisine all sourced from local organic ingredients.  We started with the western restaurant, delighting with the taste of delicate pumpkin soup, crispy duck in sesame sauce and slow-cooked tender lamb.  Click below to listen to the birds of Chiang Dao.

media:content.media:title: Woman selling longan, a lychee-like fruit grown in Thailand.
Misty mountain view from Chiang Dao Nest.
Lemongrass juice on arrival at Nest.
Rain that lasted for three days.
The road to Chiang Dao cave.
Dogs hanging out near Chiang Dao cave.
Old Chedi outside the Chiang Dao cave.

item.title: How To Survive Bowling Day When You’re Outnumbered
item.dc:creator: critters and crayons
item.category: how to survive bowling day when you're outnumbered by kids
item.description: One thing’s for sure, it is hot. It’s hot as usual here and it’s unseasonably hot everywhere else. I know that my mini-van isn’t exactly The Weather Channel, but there is something inherently wrong with seeing this everyday: My kids know that we don’t go out to play at the park until it drops to [...]
item.content:encoded:
One thing’s for sure, it is hot. It’s hot as usual here and it’s unseasonably hot everywhere else. I know that my mini-van isn’t exactly The Weather Channel, but there is something inherently wrong with seeing this everyday:

My kids know that we don’t go out to play at the park until it drops to a cool 99 degrees. If you think I’m joking when I say that 99 degrees is cool and breezy, you don’t live in South Texas. 90 degrees is jacket weather around here.

One of the things we like to do when we want to break out of the house is to go bowling. Bowling with little kids can be a challenge- but I’ve got some pain-forged tips to make your experience a little easier.

  • You shouldn’t be the only adult, particularly if you are outnumbered.
  • That’s just stupid.
  • You need at least two. The more the better, especially if you’re still outnumbered.
  • One of you is the Designated Bowler. The other is the Designated Wrangler.

Together, you form a team, each with proscribed duties and inviolable duties.

  • The Bowler. This person occupies a position forward of the those dots on the ground in your lane (whatever they’re called- you know what I’m talking about). The Bowler also serves as The Forward Security Element responsible for all child-movement between those little dots and the slippery broken-ankle-inducing front line.
  • The Wrangler. This person is responsible for all child-movement behind those little dots in your lane. This person serves as The Rear Security Element. This person does not bowl.
  • Perimeter Security. If you have more adults, then you can throw out people to the sides, notably in the path of clear escape routes in the direction of those rip-off dollar toy machines, arcade games or riding toys that eat your money and never move.

If you’re The Sole Wrangler, you’ve got a lot of ground to cover.

The Bowler’s got it easy. Here’s what The Bowler does:

The Wrangler’s just screwed. The Wrangler is the one retrieving kids playing tag with each other who are darting in front of the aspiring and supremely annoyed professional bowlers on either side of you. They’re the ones pulling little hands out of the Ball-Spitter-Outer. The Wrangler smacks fat little fingers off the computer screen before another 5 games are added to the bill. And, the Wrangler hurdles over tables and people to get to the bowling ball rack where a 15 lb ball is about to be dropped by a 2 year old on his own big toe. Guess who The Wrangler normally is. Mom The Martyr. That’s right.

A good Wrangler is a master of anticipation. Like a seasoned basketball player in a man-to-man defense, a good Wrangler always keeps her body between her opponent (insert kid or kids’ name(s) here) and her opponent’s goal (that would be any place but where you actually want them) using the devices of peripheral vision, intuition, and anticipation. Anticipation may be the most important tool of all.

A good Wrangler anticipates escape routes and danger zones. She enforces mitigating security measures and creates a makeshift physical perimeter by employing: man-made obstacles (blockades of purses, strollers, and diaper bags), pre-existing natural obstacles (bolted-down swivel chairs, and that bowling ball ejector thingy) and effective observation techniques from a reliable vantage point giving a clear view of the entire bowling alley. Standing on top of the table to scan the room usually works for me.

In case anyone is wondering: I AM A GOOD WRANGLER.

I am good, because I think like this:

Despite the disproportionate duties, bowling days really are worth any hassles. Everything, good or bad, happens inside an air-conditioned building. It’s a bonding activity. And when you go with small kids, it’s also pretty hilarious.

The slow ball tapped by a toddler’s meek touch that stops in the center of the lane is cliche. But, have you seen a 6 lb ball come back to you after it’s already stopped dead? I have. Often.

Not to brag, but when my kid pushes the ball with all the force of weak fart, it actually comes to a complete halt at the end of the lane, just on the precipice of the welcoming but denied gutter. It then begins its slothful journey back to us. If you want to get scientific about it, I figure it’s really, most probably, the effect of vibrations.

The copious and deafening strikes occuring in the lanes next to us stir the stagnant orb back to life and rock it whisperingly back in our direction. But, that’s way above toddler logic. My son squeals happily every time it happens. He, and his astonished peers, are convinced that he’s got magic bowling ball summoning powers.

There’s one of our stalled balls on its unfulfilled journey. That ball actually made it’s way back to the center of the lane as it dutifully answered my son’s convincing calls to come back before the bowling alley manager came to retrieve it for us. It happened a few more times before the guy decided to just occupy a perch down by the bowling pins until we were through.

This is all not to say that little kids never knock pins down. They do. The video here shows one of the more successful ball tosses amongst three small kids we took on one particular bowling expedition.

You can see why it took us an hour and a half to finish just 8 frames, 2 shy of a full game. The kids had culminated by then, and before the first game was even over, we took off for some pizza and bubble-gum-gummy-bear-chocolate-chip ice cream.

All things considered, you’d do well to remember the bowling alley as an option for a hot day activity. It gets you out of the sauna and you might even have some laughs between panicked screams.

When you do go, you learn quickly that bowling with toddlers is not about the number of games you finish. It’s not even about the number of frames you finish. It’s about the time you spent together. If you’re lucky and smart, maybe you won’t make yourself the martyr and you’ll give your husband the kid-wrangling duties.

But no matter what- after all the cool air, and knocked down pins, gutter balls and bruised toes, can you guess the very best part? The Bargain. Every time we go, we walk out with another cool pair of shoes for just one buck! And you can’t beat that! Look at my son’s newest shoes!

item.title: Hoover Dam/ Nevada
item.dc:creator: pgsabby
item.description: This man-made hydropower dam was very impressive to see and the size is unbelievable. The Dam is more than 700 feet high (imagine a 70-story building), As I stood and looked down on it, I got goose bumps thinking of how high I was to this massive amount of water…yikes!
item.content:encoded: This man-made hydropower dam was very impressive to see and the size is unbelievable. The Dam is more than 700 feet high (imagine a 70-story building), As I stood and looked down on it, I got goose bumps thinking of how high I was to this massive amount of water…yikes!

item.title: Fish in a butterfly
item.dc:creator: Jody and Ken
item.description: What happens to old cooking trends after they die? Case in point: we own a full-size French fish poacher.  It’s lurking in our basement like a giant carp resting on the bottom of a pond.  How it ended up there is no mystery.  It’s a beast, an unwieldy piece of steel, heavy as plate armor, [...]

Begin at the cleft in the heart and work around to the point.
Fold the tail under before baking.

item.title: Lollapalooza 2011 in Review: Day One
item.dc:creator: beargirls
item.description: Water in a box, stages so far away from each other that you might miss half a set if you try to catch two back-to-back, too-cool-for-school high schoolers and drunk middle-aged married couples lying down on blankets, blocking access to the stage – That’s Lollapalooza minus the music in a nutshell. Here’s the rest for [...]
item.content:encoded:
Water in a box, stages so far away from each other that you might miss half a set if you try to catch two back-to-back, too-cool-for-school high schoolers and drunk middle-aged married couples lying down on blankets, blocking access to the stage – That’s Lollapalooza minus the music in a nutshell. Here’s the rest for Day One.

Wye Oak

Jenn Wasner of Wye Oak

An early slot for a band like Wye Oak is almost preferable. Their music, though big-sounding for just a drummer and guitarist, is personal to the point where there needs to be a way for everyone to get to the front to hear everything from Jenn’s warm alto-range vocal timbre, to the distortion and drum-heavy pounding of their breakdowns. So, while the stage filled up by the end of Wye Oak’s set, enough time was given to the audience to be completely absorbed into the music. Though, the mood was broken quite a few times, but not by fault of the band.

By “Holy, Holy” off of the semi-recently released Civilian, their guitar amp and pedals somehow all burned out leaving a flustered Jenn Wasner to share that this was the “worst thing” that had ever happened to them. Though, that may not be so true. Back at the Canopy Club in October, the roof leaked on Jenn’s guitar forcing the band to end its set early. Someone in the crowd next to me explained that Jenn threw her back out at a recent show in his home town. So, it’s not surprising that Jenn shared her thoughts that the band was “cursed.” As soon as the stagehands switched out some equipment after Jenn stopped playing in the middle of “Plains,” Wye Oak switched back into a very dynamically intricate performance.

Andy Stack of Wye Oak

Andy skillfully slammed on drums while maneuvering one hand around a synth and various effects. And while the renditions of verses and choruses were very similar to those of their recordings, Wye Oak busted out some of the most unexpectedly crazy and sonically interesting breakdowns of the festival in songs like “Dog’s Eyes” and “I Hope You Die” (a softer song transformed into an emo/post-punk machine). Ending on “For Prayer,” during which Jenn gave off a small smirk while reciting “I guess I do believe in God,” the crowd accidentally gave off a very loud cheer during the pause before the song’s conclusion, which somewhat hindered the mood. Though Jenn and Andy, skillfully pulled through and earned an even larger applause at the conclusion of the set.
—Adam Barnett

Young the Giant

Young the Giant @ Lollapalooza 2011

Lollapalooza has a knack for adding buzz bands, bands that release a record and accumulate oceans full of critical acclaim. So here’s Young the Giant, with a self-titled released this past January and an upcoming tour with Incubus, performing at 1 p.m. to already tens of thousands of people crammed together at one of the main stages to the point where one would look at the crowd and not even attempt to get any closer; though, the speakers were loud enough to travel a quarter of a mile with barely any loss. So from my perch on top of the small hill that housed the audience, it was easy to hear, see and dance to Young the Giant’s rendition of 50s/60s rock gone indie-pop. Filing on stage to roaring applause, YtG busted out “I Got” with vocalist Sameer Ghadia shaking a tambourine and crooning into his vintage microphone. By the next song “Apartment,” the drums and bass were following these crazy and catchy rhythms, and that’s when I realized that Young the Giant is actually a lot of fun, contrary to what I initially figured from their recordings. You could pick out every instrument, and it was clear from the blatant upbeatness of the lines that each musician was having fun with what he was playing, and that opened up a world for the rest of the crowd. Plus, Ghadia is one of those vocalists who loves shaking things on stage for rhythmic effect, and everyone can relate to that. I love shaking things, even off stage. —AB

Young the Giant @ Lollapalooza 2011

The Mountain Goats

John Darnielle of the Mountain Goats

Music rose from the stage, but it wasn’t the Mountain Goats’. Erupting from the speakers was some of the most abrasive death metal I’ve heard since my metalhead phase in the 8th grade. Was it a speaker malfunction? It was actually an ironic entrance by John Darnielle and the rest of the Mountain Goats, to which they screamed and pretended to be much more hardcore than they really are (seemingly).

On to the performance: Almost everyone who talks about the Mountain Goats for press mentions that Darnielle is a “great story teller,” which is exactly what he is. In some cases, his lyrics might be considered verse, but all-in-all it’s very prose, and that’s what makes his appearance at a festival so welcoming. He isn’t attempting to “feel” his words while he performs, but he paints a lyrical and musical portrait to which the audience can listen, understand and possibly relate, but empathy (or sympathy) isn’t key to Darnielle’s art form. That said, his stories are blatantly honest, which the Lollapalooza crowd appreciated.

Jenn Wasner taking a photo of John

When Darnielle sang out, “This is a song with the same for chords I use most of the time when I’ve got something on my mind,” both Darnielle and the audience laughed, while accepting that this was true for most songwriters. During a three-song solo stint in the middle of the set, he claimed that the only reason for the solo performance was his planned performance of the song “Cubs in Five,” to which hundreds cheered whenever the “Cubs” were mentioned. Though, as my friend Mike put it, were people cheering because of Darnielle’s mentioning of their hometown, or were they supportive of his negative commentary about the team? Eventually after constant audience nagging to play the one song common music consumers know from the Mountain Goats, the full band came in with “No Children” to much applause.

They then played a very Mountain Goats-y version of Styx’ “Babe,” followed by “This Year,” for which Darnielle invited Jenn from Wye Oak to sing. However, while she jumped up and down on stage and sang the chorus, she also took a Polaroid camera, snapped a shot of John, shook it like “Hey Ya,” and chuckled at the results with the band. In short, fun was had by all, even though we didn’t get to see the photo. —AB

The Mountain Goats @ Lollapalooza 2011

Bright Eyes

Bright Eyes @ Lollapalooza 2011

It was a mad rush to go from the Mountain Goats to Bright Eyes because, while the stages were right across from each other, the Mountain Goats and Bright Eyes maintain overlapping fan bases, while many were listening to the Mountain Goats from the front of main stage where they anticipated Bright Eyes’ performance. Needless to say, I made a mad dash and unfairly used my press credentials and camera as a fake excuse to push to the front of one of the first bands for which I physically bought every release to date. Bright Eyes came in strong with “Four Winds” which, though it lacked the strings of the recording, was just as powerful with guitars and trumpet. People “went wild” by the end of “Old Soul Song.” Nate added a latin-style trumpet solo to “Lover I Don’t Have to Love,” that very much reminded me of sister-band Cursive during their Happy Hollow days. Oberst seemed hyper-aware that this was a crowd full of people who had no idea what his music was about (which is probably why he didn’t throw “Padriac My Prince” into the mix), so he dedicated his single “Shell Games” to “all the phonies,” but definitely played it well.

Laura Burhenn performing with Bright Eyes

Conor and the band definitely had the style and ability to play a festival like Lollapalooza, especially with selections from indie-rock record The Peoples’ Key now included in the setlist. But for Oberst as a performer, it doesn’t seem fitting. Oberst has toned down his pantomiming since his set at Assembly Hall, but he’s still going strong, making me wish he were still a partially introverted thirteen year old. He even went in for front-row fan hugs. As big as he’s gotten, and as much as his music, though still great, has conformed to convention, Oberst still isn’t a rock star, and he never will be. But at this point, I don’t think he can revert, especially when he’s still changing words and their rhythms, to the point where most fans can’t sing along. But with Laura Burhenn of the Mynabirds still on keys, Bright Eyes still made an impression, especially after I’m Wide Awake it’s Morning favorite “Road to Joy” played at full-power. —AB

Bright Eyes @ Lollapalooza 2011

Ratatat

Ratatat @ Lollapalooza 2011

This was my attempt to be the hip kid, the one who thought, “Everyone is going to see Girl Talk, My Morning Jacket or Coldplay. There’s no way this stage will be packed.” I was a stupid, ignorant 20-year old. Of course it was packed, because Ratatat is incredible. The set started late, but fans didn’t seem to care. They just kept pushing until, finally Mike Stroud and Evan Mast walked on stage and got every high and sober soul in the cramped stage area to shoot up hands.

Ghostly Orchestra

The sound was fantastic, with every desirable frequency present and in good amount, with a great balance between electronic production, keyboards and almost-orchestral guitar. The video screen in the background provided abstract representations of wars and chicken heads for the instrumentals available to the ears, and during “Mirando” a ghost, renaissance-era string duet appeared in hologram on-stage, completely blowing Coldplay’s simultaneous cliché’ firework and laser-light display out of the festival. —AB

Ratatat @ Lollapalooza 2011

Check out the rest of the photos for Day One here:

item.title: 5 Things the 90s Tried to Convince Us Were Cool
item.dc:creator: burkpkrohe
item.category: 5 Things the 90s Tried to Convince Us Were Coo l
item.description: Often, time is unkind. Ask Carrie Fisher. Cheap shots aside, looking back at the past, sometimes it’s hard to believe what was en vogue. This is evident if you ever had the displeasure of sitting through one of VH1’s numerous I Love the ___ shows.  I thought I would take a look back at the [...]
item.content:encoded:
Often, time is unkind. Ask Carrie Fisher. Cheap shots aside, looking back at the past, sometimes it’s hard to believe what was en vogue. This is evident if you ever had the displeasure of sitting through one of VH1’s numerous I Love the ___ shows.

 I thought I would take a look back at the decade I grew up in, the 90s, to see what passed as cool, but was most definitely not.

5. Comically Baggy Pants

In the early to mid 90s, other pizza-faced adolescents would have taunted you mercilessly for wearing the slim and straight-leg jeans that are so popular today.

I’m sure others my age remember how cool, for some reason, Jnco Jeans were. They latched on to the baggy concept with a tenacity and enthusiasm that made their product simultaneously successful and absurd. Apparently, teenagers in the 90s took a look at clowns and thought “that’s the look!”

In fact, I recently watched an old skate video from the early 90s (you should too, to get an idea of what I’m talking about) and it looked like everyone was wearing jeans at least four sizes too large.

So there you have it moms and dads of 90s kids, you can officially say “I told you so” now. I only wish I hadn’t been a part of this stupid, stupid trend. (To be clear I didn’t have Jncos, just jeans that were way too baggy)

4. Teal

The 90s was a big decade for that color in between blue and green.

It’s a little known fact that every expansion team in the 90s had to attempt to shoehorn teal or purple into their team colors. For example: the San Jose Sharks, Florida Marlins (which at least actually fits into the local flavor or Miami), Jacksonville Jaguars, etc..

Teal’s PR must have leaned hard on auto manufacturers as well because the 90s was the only decade where a metallic jade paint job was an available option. I would know because my car, a 1995 Chevy, is that ridiculous color.

But, frankly, my opinion is: get off the fence. Pick green or pick blue.

3. Super Sitcommy Sitcoms

I grew up watching Home Improvement, and I still watch it sometimes on Nick at Nite. After watching some other Nick at Nite programming, it became obvious to me that people in the 90s loved terrible sitcoms.

TV executives in the 90s triumphed laugh tracks, tired plots and obvious and usually mediocre jokes. Some networks are still continuing that shameful tradition *cough* CBS *cough* Edgy and innovative sitcoms like Arrested Development or It’s Always Sunny in Philadelphia never would have aired 15 years ago.

Actually, some of the best TV on the air at the time was on Nickelodeon and was aimed at kids. Shows like Pete and Pete, Clarissa Explains it All and Ren and Stimpy were miles ahead of most of the crap on network TV. Sure, there were a few gems such as Seinfeld and Frasier but for the most part, 90s network TV was full of schlock like Friends.

2. Tribal Tattoos

Tattoos became much more mainstream in the 90s. However, increased unoriginality came with increased acceptance. By the late 90s, every frat guy with a Coors Light habit and access to his parent’s credit card had some sort of tribal armband around his bicep.

It’s a shame that people partially responsible for the increased acceptance of tattoos were the same guys who can’t find Polynesia on a map and think the Maori is an SUV made by Subaru.

Affliction and Tapout have allowed the trend to live on to the present, but there’s no way it will last much longer…I hope.

1. Vanilla Ice

Need I say more:


Filed under: Humor, List, Uncategorized Tagged: 5 Things the 90s Tried to Convince Us Were Coo l, 90s, 90s Fads, 90s Kids, 90s Trends, The 90s

item.title: Confessions Of A First Time Camper
item.dc:creator: missmaimai
item.description: As an islander, being outdoors usually means sunbathing at a beautiful beach and snorkeling or diving in crystal, blue waters. Rarely will you get an invitation to go camping. My concept of this was basically based on Hollywood movies where the characters sit around a bonfire and sing Kumbaya. As a first time camper, my [...]
item.content:encoded:
As an islander, being outdoors usually means sunbathing at a beautiful beach and snorkeling or diving in crystal, blue waters. Rarely will you get an invitation to go camping. My concept of this was basically based on Hollywood movies where the characters sit around a bonfire and sing Kumbaya.

Not quite your usual campfire song

As a first time camper, my immediate question was, “Where would we shower?” And the usual answer was, “You don’t.”  I shower twice a day and the thought of going on for days without showering was terrifying. Baby wipes, as friends suggested, would not suffice.

Another concern of mine was safety. I don’t have a fear of ghosts but I am absolutely terrified of being attacked. And again, no thanks to many suspense Hollywood thrillers, I was afraid that we would be prey to some psycho-killer on the loose.

So those were my main concerns – hygiene and safety. “How dare they laugh,” I thought. Those are pretty valid concerns, right? Thankfully, Mike always reassured me that everything would be all right. But the truth was, there was no appeasing this shower-loving and semi-paranoid Filipina. I prepared myself for the worst.

So on our first night, just as I had predicted, I was thrown into what seemed to be the worst-case scenario. After hours of driving and being tourists, we finally decided to camp out in Monterey. We passed several state parks along Big Sur that charged an average of $35 but thought that they were too pricey. We didn’t know any better and didn’t realize that that was as cheap as they would get in touristy areas. We basically drove around for 2 hours in the dark of Monterey and had no idea where we were going to spend the night. Finally, Mike thought he had found the perfect campsite – a secluded parking area by the Monterey marine sanctuary. At that point, all I could think of was my imminent death.  In fairness to my fears, all I could see was darkness. Long story short, Mike realized that it was probably best that we moved somewhere better lit. So this is where we camped out on our first night.

camped out in the burbs of Monterey. Mike was not pleased.

Morning came and I saw everything in a different light, literally. I realized that there was nothing to be afraid of and couldn’t help but laugh at the how silly and afraid I had gotten the night before. It was then that I realized that Mike wouldn’t take me anywhere unsafe and that I should trust his judgment more.  It was also then that I made the decision to take more risks and to refrain from letting my unfounded fears stop us from living such a great adventure.

The second night, we camped at the Redwoods in Big Basin. One of my favorite campsites.

Campsite in Mendocino. We had the place all to ourselves and we got to stay for free!

Another one of our favorite campsites - Juniper Creek.

Friends' lush gardens are also a great camping site!

When campsites go bad. Would have been beautiful if not for the dead trees and humongous mosquitoes!

After that night, I learned to embrace everything about the North American outdoors – being in the middle of nowhere, sleeping amongst a sea of trees, waking up to the sound of birds singing and the wind rustling the leaves, cooking with a camp fire, bumping into wild life and yes, even peeing in the woods – and had the time of my life.

This city girl will never be the same again.

item.title: Weekly Photo Challenge: Mountains
item.dc:creator: suitablefish
item.description: Sunrise to sunset. Filed under: ArtCafe, Joie de Vivre, Weekly Photo Challenge Tagged: Grand Teton Mountains, mountain ranges, postaday2011, postaweek2011, Teton Mountains, weekly photo challenge

media:content.media:title: Mt. Owen, The Grand Teton & The Middle Teton
